subtitle: Every once in a while, a mystery emerges that is so complex,
finding answers only leads to more questions.
That is exactly what happened at Skeleton Lake.
Nestled within the stunning Himalayan mountains
lies the unassuming Roopkund Lake,
sitting a breathtaking 15,000 feet above sea level.
At first glance, this small body of water is just like a hundred others,
long frozen under the often harsh and snowy conditions.
But take a closer look,
and a disturbing picture comes into focus;
hundreds of human bones scattered around the base of the frozen water,
piled high and bleached white after years of exposure.
Some of the skeletons still have skin and hair on some parts,
preserved for years due to the cold.
The most mysterious part
was that the skeletons were all killed in the same manner,
by a strike to the head from a blunt object.
And not only that,
but the skeletons belonged to at least three different groups,
the first one being from the 7th century AD,
the second from the 10th century,
and the third - from the 19th century.
How was this possible?
How could hundreds of people, separated by thousand years,
have all been killed in the same way at the exact same place?
Moreover, who or what caused their deaths?
This mystery began with the discovery of Skeleton Lake in 1942
by an Indian forest official named Hari Kishan Madhwal.
Mr. Madhwal reportedly stumbled across the bizarre scene,
where the skeletons of approximately 800 bodies
were scattered around the area,
eerily preserved and frozen in time by the frigid temperatures.
Since the second world war was raging at that time,
the Indian officials didn't pay much attention to the victims,
believing they died after a failed landing or other military maneuvers.
It wasn't until the 1950s
that renewed interest in the dreadful site prompted an announcement to the public
and subsequent investigations into their mysterious origins.
Initially, the remains were believed to be those of traders or soldiers
who met their end along the Silk Road
from either exposure to subzero temperatures or a deadly epidemic.
However, this theory was discarded as there were no bones of any pack animals
that usually accompany traders,
or any weapons or military uniforms that would identify them as soldiers.
There was also a large number of women among the dead.
The emergence of forensic technology sparked the hope of finding out
the true identities of these faceless skeletons.
this forensic analysis was used to develop a hypothesis that the group was, in fact,
Indian pilgrims; men and women struck down by a giant hail storm
in a single tragic event occurring in the 9th century,
a theory drawn by examination of the injuries reported
within many of the skulls.
Of course, at that time,
scientists still thought that all dead bodies were from the same time period
and that they were all one big group that died together.
For this reason,
the theory that they were simple pilgrims killed by a storm
continued to gain in popularity
as archaeologists drew the conclusion that the traveling party was undertaking
a revered Indian pilgrimage occurring once every twelve years
to the city of Homkund.
According to Dr. Veena Mushrif-Tripathy,
an archeology professor at Deccan College in Pune,
the team investigating the remains at Skeleton Lake
determined the pilgrimage theory to be the most plausible,
thanks to DNA analysis indicating the group included
both male and female bodies with wide age ranges,
along with the discovery of musical instruments
and the distinct lack of weapons throughout the site.
After this, researchers believed that the mystery of Skeleton Lake
was finally solved.
But that was until 2010,
when revolutions in DNA analysis transformed the way we view the past,
giving insight into biological secrets we never thought possible.
Using this newfound technology was an exciting proposition for those seeking
to better understand the origins of Skeleton Lake.
Ayushi Nayak,
a researcher at the Max Planck Institute for the Science of Human History,
voiced this sentiment, stating,
"At a site like Roopkund where the context is highly disturbed,
and the possibilities of full-scale excavations are low,
using ancient DNA provides us with direct information
about the genetic ancestry of these individuals.
We were able to add new kinds of data through different biomolecular methods."
One discovery that would turn the mystery of Skeleton Lake on its head
and break the case wide open
was the identification and sequencing of the first ancient human genome,
which would allow scientists to pinpoint genetic origins.
The powdered bone samples from thirty-eight skeletal remains,
which were collected from the lake in 2004
and stored in the Anthropological Survey of India,
were sent to sixteen labs across the globe
for biomolecular and genomic analysis.
The result would be five years of comprehensive study,
which would uncover information that would shock the world.
Blowing the initial and well-accepted theory
of an Indian pilgrimage out of the water,
the new study showed that the thirty-eight skeletal remains
belonged to no less than three genetically distinct peoples,
deposited onto the site in multiple events throughout a 1,000-year timespan.
Of the three paleo groups found, the first belonged to South Asians,
whose bones were left over multiple events in the 7th and 10th centuries.
The second group, identified through dietary analysis,
was of South-East Asian origin and was deposited in the 19th century.
While surprising, it would be the third group
that would have scientists and archaeologists scratching their heads
and questioning everything they thought they knew
about historical human migration.
The final skeletal analysis indicated
that the remains were people of Eastern Mediterranean ancestry,
originally from the island of Crete.
These bones showed the group died in a single event in the 19th century,
but it failed to answer the question,
why were they in the Indian Himalayas, and how did they get there?
As Nayak would explain,
"Questions remain about the group of individuals that matched
closest in ancestry to modern-day Eastern Mediterranean people –
in terms of their reasons for visiting Roopkund.
Or about whether there are other sites in the region
with such accumulations of human remains."
There's no doubt that the presence
of Eastern Mediterranean people of non-Indian origin
located deep within the vast expanse of the Himalayan mountains was a shock
since there is zero historical evidence to explain their existence in the region.
Although in the ancient past, we know that the great conquests
of Alexander the Great brought many native Greeks to Asia,
the furthest they reached was western India,
and there are no accounts of Greeks
traveling so high up the Himalayan mountains.
Moreover, the Greek skeletons found at the lake
were not from the time of Alexander, but from the 19th century.
How was it possible that Greeks from Crete
went all the way to the Himalayas
only to die in a mysterious way?
It's fair to mention that the hike to this infamous site
is not for the faint of heart,
as it involves a seven-day uphill climb covering over 30 miles
and passing only one small encampment along the way.
During the weeklong expedition,
hikers would pass through enchanted oak forests
lined with wildflowers and alpine pastures known as Bugyals,
that only occur 30,000 feet above sea level.
But the fairy tale scene quickly fades to reveal
towering mountain peaks and the impressive Junargali ridge,
a razor-edged cliff jutting 16,000 feet into the sky
and offering spectacular 360-degree views of the seemingly unending Himalayas.
Roopkund Lake, now known as Skeleton Lake,
lies 650 feet below, in the shadow of this impending ridge.
With modern-day gear,
this trek is problematic at best and deadly at worst when the weather turns.
Those seeking to scale the treacherous cliff
are at risk of plummeting to their deaths.
Yet despite that,
these Greek travelers managed to reach the lake at some time in the 19th century.
How and why, was unclear.
All of these unanswered questions created more confusion than ever.
How did these ancient people die?
Was it exposure from the unrelenting elements,
known to turn on a dime from crystal clear blue skies
to fatal and discombobulating storms?
Maybe they lost their way and fell off the Junargali ridge.
Or perhaps they succumbed to acute mountain sickness,
an all too common occurrence at such high altitudes.
The initial hypothesis that their demise occurring from massive hailstorms
still couldn't explain the time between their deaths,
now known to span more than 1,000 years.
However, it frustratingly continues to be the only evidence scientists have.
Mushrif-Tripathy, who was a part of the groundbreaking 2019 investigation,
maintains that
"there are hardly six to seven skulls with trauma related to hail.
In my opinion, the mystery is not at all solved.
We have more questions than answers."
Although scientists had no idea what killed all of these people,
there were some who knew the answers.
The state of Uttarakhand in northern India
is often referred to as Devbhumi, which means "Land of Gods".
There's one goddess in particular that the Uttarakhandi adore exceedingly -
the goddess Nanda Devi.
Before Nanda became a Devi, which means goddess,
she was a princess from the Chand Dynasty.
After being forced to marry a neighboring prince against her will,
Nanda fled along the length of the great Himalayas that lay before her kingdom.
It was a cold escape,
climbing the snowy ridges of the mountain on her own.
The wind howled as she climbed higher,
tearing away the scarfs and robes which bundled the princess,
until she was bare-handed and her knees wept red against the white snow.
Then, bedraggled, Nanda collapsed against the mountain.
With her final strength, she called to the gods,
begging them to allow her to become one with the mighty mountain,
so she could escape the fate of a loveless marriage
to a man of unkempt morals.
The gods were so moved by her display that they answered her desire for escape.
Nanda merged with the mountain, becoming Nanda Devi: Goddess of Bliss,
in the graciousness of her own answered cries.
However, Nanda Devi also became infused with tremendous rage
because of all the suffering she endured.
For this reason, everyone passing this region of the Himalayas
had to be careful not to offend the goddess.
The local villages near the area have a folk song sung for generations
which serves as a warning for everyone
trying to pass the mountain of the goddess.
The song conveys a story of a local ruler who went to the mountain
hoping to gain the goddess's approval.
However, in doing so,
he took all of his courtiers, musicians, and dancers with him.
Because the pilgrimage to the peak was long,
the traveling party was constantly celebrating, dancing, and playing music.
This lack of humility angered the goddess,
who, according to the song,
sent iron balls toward the travelers, killing all of them on the spot.
Surprisingly,
this story corresponds precisely to the discovered skeletons near the lake,
most of whom were killed by a hit to the head from a blunt object.
It also explains the musical instruments found near the bodies.
Could the iron balls mentioned in the song
actually be a massive hail storm sent by an enraged mountain goddess?
Although this story gives us some important information
about the death of the victims,
it still doesn't explain why different groups of people
were killed by a hail storm at the exact same place.
And if all of the people who travel to the peak of the mountain are pilgrims,
are the Greek travelers also pilgrims?
It's interesting to note that there are many correlations
between the ancient Hellenic pantheon and the Hindu gods.
For example,
Krishna and Achilles were both killed by arrows piercing their heel –
the only vulnerable part of their body.
Both Indra and Zeus are the "kings" of the gods.
In addition, their weapons are thunderbolts –
in Indra's case, called the Vajra.
Yama and Hades are both lords of death and preside over the underworld.
They both decide the fates of the souls that pass into their realm,
and they both have hounds that accompany them –
Sharvara for Yama and Cerberus for Hades.
The Greek and Hindu gods of love – Cupid and Kamadeva,
both shoot arrows into the hearts of unsuspecting people
to make them fall in love.
The similarities are endless.
Yet these Greeks were from the 19th century,
a time period in which the Hellenic religion was long gone.
Is it possible these Greeks were worshiping the gods of Hinduism?
This also doesn't make sense
since the pilgrimage of the worshippers of Nanda Devi
is not known by anyone other than the local Himalaya Hindus,
as the story of Nanda Devi is not in any Hindu scriptures.
The legend of Nanda Devi is known only to the locals,
so how is it possible that Greeks from Crete could hear about it
and travel on a pilgrimage there?
The only other explanation could be that
the Greeks were involved in an expedition to the Himalayas,
not as pilgrims but as explorers.
Yet there are no official records of such an expedition,
and such an expedition doesn't make sense
for a nation that recently gained its independence from the Ottoman Empire
and was trying to organize itself into a proper country.
Another strange thing is that an exploratory expedition
usually takes a couple of people,
while the Greek skeletons are hundreds.
As we reach the end of this video,
we're left with more questions than answers.
Will Skeleton Lake ever uncover its ancient secrets,
or will the mystery only deepen as we discover more?
One thing holds true;
the key to understanding the secrets of this dreadful place
lies within these icy waters,
but just as the skeletons that lay scattered along its shores,
it will remain a riddle waiting to be solved.
Once again, thank you for watching.
If you want to help this video reach more people,
share it on social media and leave it a like.
And if you're new, you can subscribe by also clicking the notification button
so you know first when we post.
